importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date when the incident was reported and the official statement from WindBorne was released.
The date when United Flight 1093 completed its emergency landing in Salt Lake City.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The altitude range where WindBorne stated it adjusted operations to reduce exposure to potential balloon collisions.

keyTakeAways: A weather balloon, possibly from WindBorne, may have struck the cockpit window of United Flight 1093, resulting in a cracked windshield and minor injuries to the first officer.
The incident prompted United Airlines to divert the flight to Salt Lake City, where emergency medical care was provided to the injured pilot.
WindBorne, a California-based weather tech startup, confirmed its involvement and stated it is cooperating with the NTSB and FAA to investigate the incident.
WindBorne implemented immediate operational changes to reduce flight time between 30,000 and 40,000 feet and is advancing autonomous flight collision avoidance systems using real-time flight data.
The company is also developing new hardware designs to reduce the impact force and concentration of potential balloon impacts.
The flight, a Boeing 737 from Denver to Los Angeles, ultimately landed safely and later flew to Rockford, Illinois, for maintenance.

namedEntities.name: WindBorne
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A California-based startup focused on advanced weather forecasting and atmospheric data collection
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: WindBorne is relevant to the article because it is the company that claims one of its weather balloons may have struck the cockpit of United Flight 1093.

namedEntities.name: United Airlines
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: United Airlines is relevant because it operated the flight that experienced a cockpit window breach and emergency landing due to a potential balloon strike.

namedEntities.name: United Flight 1093
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A Boeing 737 flight from Denver to Los Angeles that experienced a window breach and emergency landing
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: United Flight 1093 is central to the incident, as it is the flight that was affected by the possible balloon impact and required an emergency diversion.

namedEntities.name: Boeing 737
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A model of commercial jet aircraft used in United Flight 1093
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Boeing 737 is relevant as the aircraft type involved in the incident, where a cockpit window was damaged by a foreign object.

namedEntities.name: Salt Lake City
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A U.S. city in Utah where the flight made an emergency landing
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The flight diverted to Salt Lake City due to the emergency, where the first officer received medical treatment for injuries.

namedEntities.name: Rockford, Illinois
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A U.S. city where United Airlines performs maintenance on its 737s
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The flight later flew to Rockford, Illinois, for scheduled maintenance after the incident.

namedEntities.name: National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: U.S. federal agency responsible for investigating transportation accidents
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The NTSB is involved in the official investigation of the flight incident.

namedEntities.name: Federal Aviation Administration (FAA)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: U.S. federal agency responsible for regulating and overseeing air traffic and safety
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The FAA is cooperating with WindBorne and the NTSB in the investigation into the balloon impact event.

namedEntities.name: LiveATC.net
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A website that provides real-time air traffic control audio recordings
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: LiveATC.net audio recordings showed the pilots declaring an emergency and maintaining calm during the incident.

namedEntities.name: FlightAware
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: FlightAware confirmed the flight's route and destination, including its subsequent travel to Rockford, Illinois.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A United Airlines Boeing 737 flight (Flight 1093) from Denver to Los Angeles experienced a cracked cockpit window, likely caused by a weather balloon from WindBorne, a California-based weather technology startup. The incident resulted in minor injuries to the first officer, prompting an emergency landing in Salt Lake City. The airline and WindBorne are cooperating with the NTSB and FAA to investigate. WindBorne has already implemented operational changes to reduce exposure during high-altitude flight phases and is developing new technologies, including autonomous flight data-based avoidance systems and improved hardware, to prevent future incidents.
title: United flightâ€™s cockpit window may have been struck by weather balloon, company says
